title: Chapter 634
content:
In Satisfy, food served two purposes: sating hunger and restoring health. An essential energy source for every player.

Which made Idan's cooking a special kind of torture.

[You have eaten spoiled food.]
[You have received food poisoning.]
[You have resisted.]
[You have consumed something inedible.]
[You have been poisoned (severe).]
[You have resisted.]

"..."

"Well? Delicious, right?"

The road to Kars stretched before them, winding through mountain valleys toward the capital of the Cho Kingdom. Grid trudged alongside Idan and Yang Fei, his stomach churning with every forced meal. A torture expert was torturing him with torture.

*I just want something edible. Forget delicious—nine out of ten dishes are literal poison.*

Feeding this slop to the Overgeared Kingdom would be a disaster. Imagine the entire government collapsing because everyone simultaneously contracted food poisoning.

*The only way to improve Idan's cooking is to keep eating it.*

So Grid sacrificed himself.

Throughout the journey, he forced Idan to cook meal after meal. It required inhuman willpower. Grid was descending into his own personal hell for the sake of his kingdom.

"Grid, have some tea."

Yang Fei approached as Grid's face turned green, a cup of steaming liquid in her hands. Her expression was almost sympathetic.

"Th-Thank you..."

[You have drunk Berenas Tea.]
[Your mind and body have stabilized. Health recovery rate increased by 10% for 1 minute.]

The foul taste coating his mouth vanished. Yang Fei was a lifesaver.

Intelligent, versatile, and apparently a tea master. Every plant she gathered along the road—grass, flowers, leaves, twigs—became something medicinal under her hands.

"Where did you learn this?" Grid asked.

"Working at Idan's restaurant for several years. Sometimes customers get food poisoning and collapse..."

"..."

An absurd answer, but it revealed Yang Fei's kind heart.

*She cares about people. She'd make a great addition to the kingdom.*

The warm impression lasted about five seconds.

"It was only a matter of time before someone died. If the restaurant closed, I'd lose my job—and all my unpaid wages."

"...Right."

Grid mentally revised his assessment. Yang Fei and Rabbit would get along perfectly.

*Actually, if I assign Yang Fei to Rabbit, she'll support him properly. His work efficiency will skyrocket.*

One thing was certain: he couldn't let Yang Fei anywhere near Lord.

*That kid makes friends with every woman regardless of age or appearance. He thinks "lover" means "friend."*

Of course, young Lord remained oblivious. The problem was the women didn't.

*They all dream of marrying a prince... Wait.*

A thought struck Grid as he considered his son.

*What happens when the empire takes twelve-year-old Lord as a hostage?*

Every noblewoman in the imperial capital would fall for him.

*My son is wonderful!*

Every parent thought their child was beautiful—even hedgehogs praised their young. Naturally, Grid believed Lord was the continent's greatest genius. His confidence towered like a mountain.

*In the empire, Lord would have so much room to... No. Lord can't become a hostage.*

*Clang.*

Grid touched the necklace Lord had given him.

*For his sake, I need enough power to resist the empire. I won't let him suffer.*

Bearing Idan's cooking was nothing compared to protecting his son.

Grid steeled himself as Idan began butchering a freshly hunted monster.

***

"This is harder than I thought."

Muto ran a small-to-medium trading company with a monthly volume approaching ten thousand gold. Currently ranked third among all merchants, he'd come to the East Continent seeking opportunity.

His dream: pioneer new trade routes, expand his customer base, dominate the market.

Reality: the East Continent was brutal.

NPCs refused to trade regardless of their status. High-level monsters made traveling between settlements a nightmare.

*The reputation I built on the West Continent means nothing here. I'm basically starting over.*

If he could just establish a customer base, the exotic goods alone would catapult him to the top of the merchant rankings. Increased trading volume. Massive profits. A brilliant future.

Ten days without a single sale had dulled that enthusiasm.

*If the locals believed I could travel freely between continents, business would explode.*

But they didn't. The East Continent inhabitants thought Muto had been swept here by accident—that intercontinental travel was impossible.

"Ugh. Frustrating."

Back on the West Continent, Muto had mainly supplied Earl Butin of the Saharan Empire. The earl's territory was a noble resort, and Muto sold luxury goods there.

Then Reidan started selling sand as a longevity remedy.

The nobles bought into the ridiculous formula: *Earl Butin's goods = inferior to Reidan's miracle cure.* Interest in Muto's valuables plummeted overnight. He'd become insignificant.

The East Continent was his chance to recover. Without expanding here, his company's declining trade volume would bury him.

*At this rate, I'll drop to seventh rank.*

Losing rank meant losing sponsors. His pride as a merchant couldn't withstand that humiliation.

*Once I reach Kars, I'll meet the Cho King. If I can showcase Western culture... hm?*

Muto stopped mid-stride, his hired Zentu mercenaries halting behind him.

A spectacular scene unfolded in the mountain valley ahead.

"This is the secret technique passed down through my family! Filleting! My skills have been honed for this very moment!"

"N-No, that's not a carp—that's a mermaid..."

"It's still half fish. What's the problem?"

"...?"

A surreal sight.

Level 300 mermaid monsters trembled as a middle-aged man advanced with a kitchen knife. More impressive was the black-haired man desperately trying to stop him.

*Grid...?*

The first legendary class. The first king. The most famous player in the world.

*Why is he here?*

Coincidence?

Muto's bewildered expression transformed into a smile.

*Fate.*

Muto had every reason to hate Grid. Reidan's longevity remedy had destroyed his business. Grid was directly responsible for his fall. Resentment should have been natural.

But in this moment, those feelings evaporated.

He was bound to Grid by fate's strings.

"I was going to rest in that valley, but someone's already there."

"Should we move on?" a mercenary asked.

Muto shook his head. "If you ask him to leave, he'll cut all your heads off."

"...?"

The mercenaries frowned. They were Zentu's strongest warriors—Muto had hired them specifically for that reputation. Yet this black-haired stranger could kill them all?

"Unacceptable," one muttered.

Zentu sat near the former queen rat community, destroyed months ago. To survive the constant rat attacks, every inhabitant had trained relentlessly, earning the title of warrior. They had immense pride in their skills.

"Let's see if he's really that strong."

The mercenaries' discomfort was palpable.

"Don't eat mermaids! That's basically cannibalism!"

*Peeng!*

*Pepepepeok!*

"...?"

The valley erupted.

Swordsmanship and magic detonated simultaneously as the black-haired man moved.

"Th-This is impossible."

The mercenaries stood speechless.

They could barely handle Jam Valley mermaids one-on-one. Those creatures were comparable to the poisonous rats in strength.

The black-haired man had just slaughtered dozens in seconds. The difference in power was absolute.

"See? Different class entirely. Don't you Zentu warriors admire strength? Isn't he strong?"

*Gulp.*

The mercenaries didn't respond. They could only swallow, goosebumps crawling across their skin.

*If we'd encountered him unaware...*

*We'd be like those mermaids.*

The thought chilled them.

*Huh?*

Then they blinked.

The black-haired man had pulled out a needle and thread. He was... sewing?

"Wh-What?"

The mercenaries stared.

Muto was even more surprised.

*Sewing cloth? How can Grid, a blacksmith, work with fabric?*

He wasn't just a celebrity. Every accidental encounter revealed something new. Grid was a constant source of fascination.

Muto was certain now.

*This is my chance.*

Today's coincidental meeting would be the opportunity of a lifetime.

"Let's go. We'll introduce ourselves first."

Muto took a deep breath to suppress his tension and excitement before approaching Grid with his mercenaries.

The smell of rotting garbage grew stronger with each step.

He didn't care.
